questions.text: Which of the following test is best correlates well with histologic inflammation and predicts relapses in a patient with ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Faecal Calprotectin

Faecal calprotectin is the best test for correlating with histologic inflammation and predicting relapses in ulcerative colitis because it is a sensitive and specific marker of neutrophil activity in the intestinal mucosa. It reflects the degree of mucosal inflammation and has been extensively validated to monitor disease activity and predict flare-ups.

Faecal lactoferrin, although an inflammation marker, is less sensitive and specific compared to calprotectin.

Faecal elastase and faecal chymotrypsin are markers of pancreatic exocrine function and are not related to intestinal inflammation or ulcerative colitis activity.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical findings is not seen in patient of ulcerative colitis ?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is D: Peri-anal fistula

  • Peri-anal fistula is not a feature of ulcerative colitis; it is more typical of Crohn’s disease due to its transmural inflammation leading to fistula formation.
  • Tympanitic note over liver ( normally dullness)  can be present in ulcerative colitis due to toxic megacolon.
  • Tenderness over colon is common in active disease because of mucosal inflammation.
  • Bleeding on digital rectal examination is frequent due to friable mucosa and ulceration.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about microscopic features of Crohn’s disease?

choices.text: Non caseating granuloma in all layers of bowel wall

questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Subepithelial collagen bands

  • Subepithelial collagen band ≥10 um on biopsy is a feature of collagenous colitis. Crohn’s has transmural involvement with non-caseating granuloma in all layers of bowel wall.

questions.text: All of the following are used to assess severity of ulcerative colitis except?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: BP < 90/60 mm Hg

  • BP value < 90/60 mm Hg would be seen with massive GI haemorrhage. UC causes daily blood loss but not substantial enough to cause hemodynamic instability.

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be seen in patients with Crohn’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is D: Proctitis

  • Proctitis, or inflammation confined to the rectum, is rare in Crohn’s disease as it more commonly involves skip lesions and ileum/colon; proctitis is a feature of ulcerative colitis.
  • Entero-vesical fistula is a common complication of Crohn’s disease due to transmural inflammation causing abnormal connections between the intestine and bladder.
  • Enterocutaneous fistula, where the intestine connects to the skin surface, occurs in Crohn’s disease from penetrating inflammation.
  • Normally, calcium binds oxalate forming an insoluble complex that is excreted in stool, but when calcium preferentially binds unabsorbed fatty acids instead due to malabsorption caused by CD, free oxalate is left unbound and more readily absorbed by the colon into the bloodstream. This causes calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct radiological finding of ischemic colitis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Thumb print sign

  • The thumb print sign is a classic radiological finding in ischemic colitis, caused by submucosal hemorrhage and edema leading to mucosal and submucosal thickening that resembles thumbprints on imaging.
  • String sign is seen in Crohn’s disease due to a narrowed, strictured segment of bowel.
  • Pipe stem colon/ lead pipe colon refers to the loss of haustral folds seen in long standing ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: IBD is usually associated with extraintestinal features. Which of the following hepatobiliary features is not seen in Patients with IBD
questions.solution:
Correct answer is D: Primary biliary cholangitis

Hepatobiliary disease is seen in patients with IBD as extraintestinal feature. Usually seen are

  1. Fatty liver due to steroid therapy and chronic illness
  2. Cholelithiasis due to ileitis causing malabsorption of bile acids
  3. PSC due to association with p-ANCA

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about joint involvement seen in patient with IBD?

choices.text: Migratory peripheral arthritis, Sacroilitis and HLA B27 positive
Erosive small joint arthritis, Sacroilitis and HLA B27 positive
Migratory peripheral arthritis, tenosynovitis and HLA B27 positive
Erosive small joint arthritis, tenosynovitis and HLA B27 positive

questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Migratory peripheral arthritis, Sacroilitis and HLA B27 positive

  • HLA B27 positivity is frequently found in patients with sacroiliitis and ankylosing spondylitis associated with IBD.
  • Erosive small joint arthritis and tenosynovitis are less characteristic of IBD-related arthritis; erosive arthritis is more typical of rheumatoid arthritis, whereas IBD arthritis generally is non-erosive and involves large joints in a migratory pattern.

questions.text: 28-year-old woman with history of migraine presents with 3 months history of bloody diarrhoea and tenesmus. Labs show Hb 10 gm%, CRP positive and sigmoidoscopy showing erythema, mucosal friability starring from rectum and extending proximally. Which of the following drug will be started for management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Mesalamine

  • Mesalamine is the first-line treatment for mild to moderate ulcerative colitis, as it directly reduces mucosal inflammation and is effective in inducing and maintaining remission.
  • Sulphasalazine also works but has more side effects due to its sulfapyridine component, making mesalamine the preferred choice.
  • Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant reserved for steroid-dependent or refractory cases and is not used as initial therapy.
  • Methylprednisolone is a corticosteroid used for moderate to severe flares or when patients do not respond to mesalamine, not as initial treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following small molecule is approved for treatment of ulcerative colitis
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Tofacitnib

  • Small molecules (drugs with molecular weight <1 kDa) are a new class of orally administered medications developed for IBD that lack the immunogenicity associated with monoclonal antibodies.
  • Tofacitinib is a reversible and competitive JAK inhibitor used for mild to moderate UC refractory to biologicals
  • Option B blocks biologic activity of IL-12 and IL-23. Option C works by blocking TNF-α.
  • The advantage of small molecules is their ability to diffuse through cell membranes into the intracellular space and alter cytokine signaling pathways.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with ulcerative colitis presents with severe abdominal distension, pain, fever, and tachycardia. Abdominal X-ray shows colonic dilatation >6 cm. Ultrasound show no free fluid in peritoneal cavity. What is the first-line medical management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: intravenous corticosteroids

  • The first-line medical management for a patient with severe colonic dilatation (>6 cm) on X-ray in the context of ulcerative colitis is intravenous corticosteroids, typically methylprednisolone 40 to 60 mg daily. This treatment quickly reduces severe colonic inflammation and systemic toxicity. Note that our patient does not have perforation of bowel as there is no free fluid in peritoneal cavity
  • If there is no improvement within this period, escalation to second-line medical therapies such as infliximab or cyclosporine may be tried to avoid surgery.
  • Early surgical consultation is recommended to prepare for intervention if medical therapy fails.

questions.text: Leading cause of death in patients with Crohn’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: infection

  • The leading cause of death in patients with Crohn’s disease is infection, particularly sepsis related to complications such as postoperative infections, bowel perforation, and immunosuppression.
  • Approximately 25-40% of deaths are directly attributable to Crohn’s disease complications including infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most commonly acquired diarrheal illness acquired in the hospital?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Clostridium difficile

  • The rate of faecal colonization by Cl. difficile increases in proportion to length of hospital stay and is often ≥20% among adult patients hospitalized for >2 weeks.
  • It is acquired exogenously by patients most often in the hospital or nursing home.
  • Spores of toxigenic C. difficile are ingested and can survive gastric acidity. They then germinate in the small bowel, and colonize the lower intestinal tract producing toxins  that cause disruption of epithelial-cell barrier function, diarrhoea, and pseudomembrane formation

questions.text: Patient on ceftriaxone develops watery loose stools and low-grade fever. Blood counts show TLC of 15000 cells/cu.mm. which of the following test will help in quick detection of incriminating organism?

choices.text: NAAT for toxin A and Toxin B in stool
EIA for toxin A and toxin B in stool

questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: NAAT for toxin A and Toxin B in stool

  • NAAT / PCR is part of diagnostic criteria of PMC and gives high diagnostic sensitivity and specificity.

Option B: EIA has high sensitivity but lacks specificity.

Option C: is specific but not sensitive as pseudo membranes take time to develop.

Option D: can be used but Harrison says turnaround time is too slow for practical use.
